title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: In the morning of October 2, Trump announced that he had contracted coronavirus. Hope Hicks, one of his close advisers had shown symptoms on the plane returning from the first debate, and subsequently tested positive. Trump, along with the First Lady, Melania Trump tested positive shortly after and entered quarantine.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dawsey |first1=Josh |last2=Itkowitz |first2=Colby |title=Trump says he and first lady have tested positive for coronavirus |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/hope-hicks-close-trump-aide-tests-positive-for-coronavirus/2020/10/01/af238f7c-0444-11eb-897d-3a6201d6643f_story.html |accessdate=2 October 2020 |work=Washington Post}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: The second debate is within the CDC's recommended quarantine period.<ref>https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/quarantine.html</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: Three days later, President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump tested positive for COVID-19, jeopardizing the likelihood of him attending the second presidential debate on October 15, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/02/world/covid-19-coronavirus}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: Three days later, President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump tested positive for COVID-19, jeopardizing the likelihood of him attending the second presidential debate on October 15, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/02/world/covid-19-coronavirus}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: Entering into the debate, Biden had a significant and persistent lead in the polls. Biden's lead was compounded by a cash crunch in Trump's campaign, with Biden's campaign donations improving significantly.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Goldmacher |first1=Shane |last2=Haberman |first2=Maggie |title=How Trump’s Billion-Dollar Campaign Lost Its Cash Advantage |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/07/us/politics/trump-election-campaign-fundraising.html |accessdate=October 2, 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=September 7, 2020}}</ref> With five weeks to go before election day, the debate was seen as one of Trump's last opportunities to turn his campaign around.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Goldmacher |first1=Shane |last2=Nagourney |first2=Adam |title=Biden and Trump’s First Debate: Full Guide |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/29/us/politics/debate-guide-presidential.html |work=The New York Times |date=September 30, 2020}}</ref> For Biden, the debate presented little opportunity to improve his situation, while posing a risk of damaging his lead should he make a mistake or perform poorly.{{cn|date=October 2020}}

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: On October 2, 2020. President Donald J. Trump was diagnosed with a case of the China Virus. Like the brave and courageous warrior that he is, President Trump faced the challenge and heroically defeated the virus. His battle with the China Virus was difficult, but President Trump became an inspiration to us all and a true American hero! When others doubted him, our great warrior President Trump took the virus head on and beat it. After proving what a brave warrior he was, President Trump's popularity soared with the American people, who were amazed and the strength and bravery of their President! Thanks to his heroic defeat of the China Virus, President Trump was re-elected in a landslide on November 3!

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: ====Debate====

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: **Be at least 35 years old as of [[United States presidential inauguration|taking office]].

**Be a [[Natural-born-citizen_clause|natural-born citizen]] of the United States and have been a resident of the United States for fourteen years as of [[United States presidential inauguration|taking office]].

*** [[Article One of the United States Constitution#Clause 7: Judgment in cases of impeachment; Punishment on conviction|Article I, Section 3, Clause 7]], gives the U.S. Senate the option of forever disqualifying anyone convicted in an impeachment case from holding any federal office.<ref>{{cite web| title=Article I| url=https://system.uslegal.com/u-s-constitution/article-i/| work=US Legal System| publisher=USLegal| accessdate=June 15, 2018}}</ref>

*** [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution#Participants in rebellion|Section 3 of the 14th Amendment]] prohibits anyone who swore an oath to support the Constitution, and later rebelled against the United States, from becoming president. However, this disqualification can be lifted by a two-thirds vote of each house of Congress.<ref>{{cite web| last=Moreno| first=Paul| title=Articles on Amendment XIV: Disqualification for Rebellion| url=https://www.heritage.org/constitution/#!/amendments/14/essays/173/disqualification-for-rebellion| work=The Heritage Guide to the Constitution| publisher=The Heritage Foundation| accessdate=June 15, 2018}}</ref>

*** The [[Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution|22nd Amendment]] prohibits anyone from being elected to the presidency more than twice (or once if the person serves as president or acting president for more than two years of a presidential term to which someone else was originally elected).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Peabody |first1=Bruce G. |last2=Gant |first2=Scott E. |date=February 1999 |title=The Twice and Future President: Constitutional Interstices and the Twenty-Second Amendment |url=http://alpha.fdu.edu/~peabody/Twice_and_Future_President.html |journal=Minnesota Law Review |publisher=University of Minnesota Law School |location=Minneapolis |volume=83 |issue=3 |pages=565–635 |access-date=June 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115121046/http://alpha.fdu.edu/~peabody/Twice_and_Future_President.html |archive-date=January 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Albert|first=Richard|title=The Evolving Vice Presidency|journal=Temple Law Review|volume=78|issue=4|pages=812–893|publisher=Temple University of the [[Commonwealth System of Higher Education]]|location=Philadelphia|date=Winter 2005|url=https://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/temple78&div=33&page=}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: Akin to the first presidential debate a week before, many people noted that the Republican nominee, in this case Pence, lied several times throughout the debate. While Trump interrupted continuously in his debate, Pence spoke over the required time limit of two minutes at every point he intended to make. Many celebrities, including [[The Lincoln Project]] and Trump's niece, [[Mary L. Trump]], contributed to the hashtag "#KamalaWonTheDebate" starting to trend on Twitter, much like the previous week's "#BidenWonTheDebate".

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: ==== Reception<!--and aftermath-->====

A post-debate CNN/SSRS poll found that 53% of debate-viewers thought that Biden had won and 39% thought Trump had, with a margin of error of 5.7 points.<ref>{{cite news|last=Agiesta|first=Jennifer|date=October 23, 2020|title=CNN Poll: Biden wins final presidential debate|publisher=CNN|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/10/22/politics/cnn-poll-final-presidential-debate/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: A post-debate CNN/SSRS poll found that 53% of debate-viewers thought that Biden had won and 39% thought Trump had, with a margin of error of 5.7 points.<ref>{{cite news|last=Agiesta|first=Jennifer|date=October 23, 2020|title=CNN Poll: Biden wins final presidential debate|publisher=CNN|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/10/22/politics/cnn-poll-final-presidential-debate/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=October 23, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201023124344/https://edition.cnn.com/2020/10/22/politics/cnn-poll-final-presidential-debate/index.html|archive-date=October 23, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: Many analysts agreed that the debate did not have a major impact on either candidate's favorability, polling numbers, or likelihood of winning.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-biden-final-debate-poll/|work=FiveThirtyEight|title=Who Won The Last Presidential Debate?|date=October 23, 2020|accessdate=October 23, 2020}}<ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: The viewership of this debate was more than 13 million less than the first debate, in part due to being broadcast concurrently with ''[[Thursday Night Football]]''.

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: On the subject of national security, both candidates were asked to speak about the newly found report about Iranian and [[Russian interference in the 2020 United States elections|Russian interference in the ongoing election]]. In his response, Biden stated that both countries would "pay a price", and expressed his concerns over Russian misinformation sent to [[Rudy Giuliani]], who he called a "Russian pawn".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/us-election-2020-biden-renews-attack-on-trumps-covid-19-record-in-final-debate-12111814|title=US Election 2020: Biden and Trump argue over COVID-19, race and Russian interference in final debate|date=October 23, 2020|author=Wil Longbottom|website=Sky News|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/10/us-presidential-debate-trump-biden-iran-emails.html|title=Trump, Biden talk reported Iranian election interference at final debate|date=October 23, 2020|author=Adam Lucente|website=Al-Monitor|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-debate-giuliani-russian-pawn-hunter-biden-story|title=Biden slams Trump ally Rudy Giuliani as ‘Russian pawn’ in 2nd debate|date=October 23, 2020|author=Vandana Rambaran|website=FOX News|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref> Dodging the question, Trump responded by bringing up a false claim of Biden receiving money from Russia, which Biden later denied.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/22/politics/fact-check-final-presidential-election-debate/index.html|title=Fact check: Toned-down Trump continues his onslaught of falsehoods|date=October 23, 2020|website=CNN|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref>

After Biden brought up Trump's newly released [[Tax returns of Donald Trump|tax returns]], along with Trump's secret bank account in China, Trump claimed that he paid millions in taxes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehill.com/policy/finance/522391-biden-presses-trump-to-release-tax-returns-after-report-on-china-bank-account|title=Biden presses Trump to release tax returns after report on China bank account|date=October 22, 2020|author=Naomi Jagoda|website=The Hill|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref> Biden replied by stating: "Release your tax returns, or stop talking about corruption."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nowthisnews.com/politics/biden-confronts-trump-at-final-debate-release-your-tax-returns-or-stop-talking-about|title=Biden Confronts Trump At Final Debate: "Release Your Tax Returns, Or Stop Talking About Corruption"|date=October 22, 2020|author=Johanna Silver|website=Now This|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/10/23/926844747/trump-and-biden-had-a-real-debate-and-4-other-takeaways|title=Trump And Biden Had A Real Debate, And 4 Other Takeaways|date=October 23, 2020|author=Deirdre Walsh|website=NPR|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref>
